title: dominic raab general election lose seat east surrey brexit poll
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Foreign secretary who defies constituents over Brexit could be ousted in tactical voting, survey suggestsDominic Raab, the foreign secretary, has played down the prospect of becoming “the next Portillo” at the election, as polls suggest he risks losing his seat due to tactical voting.At the 1997 general election, Michael Portillo, then defence secretary, became a high-profile scalp and a symbol of the party’s defeat by Labour when a string of veteran Conservative MPs lost their seats.Mr Raab’s seat, Esher and Walton in Surrey, voted 58 per cent for Remain in the 2016 EU referendum, while the former Brexit secretary is a vocal Leave supporter.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA Deltapoll survey indicates he now only holds a five-point lead over Monica Harding, his Liberal Democrat opponent.The Tories have held the seat since 1910 but tactical switching by Labour supporters or a higher turnout among the under-40s could hand the seat to the Lib Dems.Created with Sketch. Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1725 Lancaster and Fleetwood1725 Lancaster and FleetwoodWhen Deltapoll asked how people would vote if they saw it as a contest between the Tories and Lib Dems, the two parties were tied at 48 per cent each, The Observer reported.Mr Raab, who had a healthy majority of 23,298 at the last election, said he was “not really” worried about losing his seat but acknowledged that “with a seat like mine you never take anything for granted”.Raab’s single market praise is the latest Brexiteer mockery of us allReject Johnson’s ‘grand delusion’ and back Lib Dems, says HeseltineRaab on target list in Lib Dem push for Remain-backing seatsSwinson admits Lib Dem bar charts ‘should be accurately labelled’Last month at a local hustings, he was “literally booed by half the room”, according to one constituent, and there was “continued heckling” as he gave his closing speech.When he said the Tories would deliver a “moderate Brexit” the room erupted in laughter, The New European reported.He told Sky News’s&nbspSophy&nbspRidge on Sunday: “The polls are all fluid and all over the place, but one thing it does show you, my constituency and up and down the country, is the risk of a hung parliament and that is a very real risk if you vote any other way than Conservative.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by email“But we’ve got a really positive plan to get Brexit done, to get the country moving forward, and I’m confident taking that to the voters.”Johnson’s lead halved, putting UK in ‘hung parliament territory’Ms Harding has tweeted that suggestions Mr Raab – and even Boris Johnson – could lose their seats are “reasons to be (cautiously) cheerful” and urged constituents to vote tactically.She also accused Mr Johnson of giving “bare-faced lies” in an interview with LBC.Asked if there was “nervousness” over Donald Trump’s visit during the election campaign, he said: “I don’t think so. title: uk general election debates tv
story: So when are they, how can you watch, and who will be taking part The first debate was between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn on ITV on November .This was followed by a BBC Question Time Leaders Special, hosted by Fiona Bruce. Conservative, Labour, SNP and the Lib Dem party leaders took questions from the audience on November .Further TV General Election coverage will include:A snap election debate poll saw a narrow win for Johnson over rival Corbyn in the head-to-head.Corbyn refused nine times to say whether he would back his own Brexit deal in a bruising TV clash.The PM repeatedly pressed the Labour boss to answer in their first live debate ahead of the December  poll.The debate on November , hosted by Julie Etchingham, also saw the leaders clash over the NHS.Corbyn accused Johnson of a plot to sell out the NHS to Donald Trump.Boris replied: “It is completely untrue.“The only reason this comes up is because Mr Corbyn is trying to conceal the void at the heart of his Brexit policy and refusing to answer the question of which side he will take.The Liberal Democrats launched a legal challenge over ITVs decision to exclude leader Jo Swinson from the debate between Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson, and are reportedly considering doing the same against the BBC.Following ITVs original announcement, Swinson tweeted: Scared, boys Speaking outside the High Court after filing for a judicial review, party president Sal Brinton said: People know more about where they stand on Brexit than for which party they will vote for.So it is vital for our democracy to have both sides of the Brexit debate represented at the top table of the leaders debates.In a letter earlier sent to ITVs chief exec, she wrote: Voters of this country deserve to hear from a Remainer on the debate stage, not just from the two men who want to deliver Brexit.There is no reasonable justication for excluding Liberal Democrats from the debate. Liberal Democrats are the strongest national party of Remain.We secured more votes than both Labour and the Conservatives in the European elections earlier this year and have enjoyed fantastic local and by-election successes across the country.The Lib Dems have vowed to cancel Brexitthey win the election.An ITV spokesperson said: ITV intends to offer viewers comprehensive and fairly balanced General Election coverage.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clive james genius tribute act
story: Words were almost beyond him by this stage. Between gasps for air, though, he managed to hand the paper over with a single instruction.“Read that.” I did.It was a review written by Clive James, The Observer’s legendary television critic, who died this week, at the age of .The year, I now discover from a collection of his work called The Crystal Bucket, was  and it must have been slim pickings for him that Sunday.There was no Eurovision Song Contest or Miss World or even an episode of The Incredible Hulk for him to dismantle. Instead he was setting the scene on a men’s downhill skiing race, at Kitzbuhel, covered by BBC’s Grandstand.“A man referred to as ‘Britain’s sole representative’ came plummeting down the Stre. ‘He won’t be looking for a first place today’, said David Vine, ‘he’ll be looking for experience’.“At that very instant — not a bit later, but while David was actually saying it — Britain’s sole representative was upside down and travelling into the crowd at mph. Spectators were mown down asby grapeshot.The air was full of snow, beanies, mittens, bits of wood. You had to be watching to get the full impact. It was kind of perfection.”The writing, it’s fair to say, hit me with the same force.My tiny, ten-year-old mind was officially blown. I’d no idea newspapers could be funny, until that moment. They were places behind which grown-up men went to hide and frown and tutt, not to be reduced to helpless, weeping wrecks.Nor did I have any idea watching the television could be a job. Paid  To watch Grandstand It was beyond anyone’s comprehension then and, slightly weirdly, after  years in the job, it’s still almost beyond my comprehension now.All of that is thanks to Clive James reinventing the role of television reviewer which, up until his arrival in , was a stuffy, reverential task performed by men, at the flat-lining end of their careers, who were still slightly in awe of the magic box in the corner of the living room.Clive James was none of those things. An Australian, he was an ambitious outsider and populist who had the honesty to point out that TV might well be a miracle of technology and incredibly popular but it wasn’t half rubbish as well.That’s the easy bit, of course. What set James apart from every other writer in Fleet Street was the poetic style and wit he did it with every single week.Since his death, from cancer, the obituaries have rightly flagged up all the one-liners which have set the industry standard ever since.He famously referred to Arnold Schwarzenegger as, “A brown condom full of walnuts”, and said of F commentator Murray Walker: “Even in moments of tranquility, Walker sounds like a man whose trousers are on fire.”The incredibly galling thing for anyone who’s trained as a journalist, though, was that James was an instinctively brilliant hack without ever wasting a day on his local newspaper.Here he is, luring me in, with another poetic intro from December .“Never since Damocles danced beneath the sword has there been anything like the World Disco Dancing Championships , brought to you live from the ravishing Empire Ballroom, Leicester Square.”Not for Clive James the high falutin’ marginal stuff, on BBC, you see, though he could do that as well. Unfashionable as it was at the time, he reviewed the television people actually watched.It meant Sundays became an event, across the nation, and our house was a minor warzone as my sister and me plotted and fought to become the first person to read his latest reviews.Those happy battles couldn’t last, though. The medium that bewitched Clive James eventually seduced him and, in , at the peak of his writing power, he became ITV’s Clive James On Television.Evenyou’re too young to remember this show, then you still most certainly live with the consequences of a programme where James held up for ridicule bad singing, from Margarita Pracatan, and a Japanese game show called Endurance, where contestants would be subjected to physical and mental torture with rats, lizards and water.At the time we thought it was some weird World War Two hangover the Japanese were working out of their system.We know now Clive James was in fact inventing the future of British television and I’m A Celebrity.The irony of this, and the debt I owe him, is not lost on me.Pick up any national newspaper today and you’ll find half a dozen journalists who owe their style, as well as the roof over their head and the food on the table, to the genius of Clive James.As you’ll quickly discoveryou read The Crystal Bucket and his November ,  review for another British TV staple, I just happen to be the most brazen tribute act.“The Royal Variety Show was hosted by Max Bygraves, who tried the time-honoured gimmick of singing the finale at the start.‘Andyou don’t like our finish, you doan have to stay for the show.’Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: voting general election opinion polls mistake
story: There were predictions for a thumping defeat — for Boris’s opponents.The YouGov poll commissioned by The Times talked of the Tories taking as many as  seats in next month’s General Election, with Labour bagging , the Scots Nats managing  and the dribbly Lib Dems back in minibus territory with just  predicted wins.As I say, disastrous.You may think I am being sarcastic. “Come off it,” you’ll say, “this was just the boost cheerful piglet Boris will have wanted. How it must raise morale among his troops!”And what a relief to the country it will be to read this prediction of a spanking for Jeremy Corbyn and his hate-filled boot boys.Christmas has come early, you may be tempted to think.If the poll also means putting a cork in that gobby Sturgeon creature — the one who wants to prop up Corbyn in exchange for billions of pounds and another Scottish independence referendum — well, great.And as a bonus it might also restore some reality to that delusional Miss Prim, Jo “I’m Going To Be Prime Minister” Swinson. What a delicious thoughtshe takes a custard pie in the eye. I know, I know, it’s tempting.But I’m afraid I am utterly serious. This poll was the last thing Boris needed at the moment. It was deeply unhelpful and may well land us with the hung Parliament that would paralyse our country and wreck Brexit.There is, as Mr Johnson’s backroom svengali Dominic Cummings pointed out this week, a terrible danger of complacency. That works on at least two levels.First, predictions of a solid Tory win could make vital swing voters think: “Actually, Boris will win without my vote, so I’ll stick to my old, tired loyalties because habits die hard and it will stop my leftie in-laws giving me a hard time.”Second, the YouGov poll could make Conservative candidates and their campaigners feel they need not try so hard. Bad, bad idea. Voters soon spota party is becoming cocky and they don’t like it. One hint of self-satisfaction can be fatal.The moment things are said to have turned badly for Neil Kinnock in the  election was when he swaggered on stage at a Sheffield rally in the last week of the campaign and started saying: “All right, all right.”Labour were ahead in the polls at that point and it looked asKinnock thought he had already won. A couple of days later, the boastful booby lost.The ancient Greeks had a word for that sort of excessive pride: Hubris. Boris Johnson is a classicist, so let’s hope he bears it in mind. The Tories may be running a campaign based on positive vibes and blue-fringed sunshine but this is really no time for optimism.Polling day — the real poll, the one that counts — is still a fortnight away. Most voters will not mark their X on ballots until two weeks today.There is still an awfully long way to go. In opera, it ain’t over ’til the fat lady sings. Diane Abbott becomes Home Secretary, she could well reclassy any references to portly sopranos as hate speech.In politics, it ain’t over ’til the election-night programme has ended.The Conservatives could still drop an almighty blooper. One misjudged phrase from Jacob Rees-Mogg, Michael Gove or Dominic Raab could still sink the canoe.Modern politics moves incredibly fast. Just look at how Jeremy Corbyn was given a comprehensive debagging this week by TV inquisitor Andrew Neil.Corbyn entered that interview studio all full of himself. Thirty minutes later he was, in a political sense, stripped down to his skimpies and string vest, knees a-knocking. More than  years in Parliament, he had been undone in just  minutes. Or so it looks at present.That’s the other thing. Opinion polls are a snapshot of public voting intentions at a particular time in a particular week.Just because they are collated by London wonks with pink-framed spectacles and designer haircuts and baffling bar charts, that does not mean they are right.In fact, there’s a good case for saying that the more “clever” political analysts are, the more likely they are to be wrong.I have spoken to numerous Tory campaigners in the past few weeks and none of them thinks Boris is romping to victory. Time and again, you hear: “It’s tight. We could yet lose this.”Look at the opinion polls in the last days before the EU referendum, which suggested Remain would win.Look at the poll which predicted a Yes win less than a month before the Scots independence referendum in .That galvanised the No campaign and made voters think: “Yikes, there’s a chance the other side could win.”Voters do not always tell pollsters the truth. The sheer nastiness of Corbyn’s cronies, with all those anti-Semitism claims, could be making the public reluctant to admit its support for Labour.Two years ago, “everyone said” Labour hadn’t a hope of preventing a Conservative majority. “Everyone said” is a deadly presumption. Labour did indeed stop Theresa May from winning that election cleanly, and look at the mess it caused.This time round, cocooned and comforted by those opinion polls, “everyone says” Boris has it in the bag. Well, he hasn’t.The only way to stop Corbyn is to vote against him. Staying at home on December  could be the worst mistake you made. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remainers ignore racism lies to stop brexit

They will ignore the sickening racism, the lies, the terrorist friends and the economic lunacy of Corbyn’s Labour and back them anyway.Some Tory Remainers may vote Lib-Dem, complacently thinking Boris will win anyway. That may prove fatal.Tories, and all Leave voters, must be resolute. Only a Tory majority will secure Brexit and defeat Corbyn. If you want it, you MUST vote for it.The Brexit Party will not win anywhere. Unless you are a lelong Labour voter who would NEVER vote Tory, ­opting for Nigel Farage over Boris now actively threatens Brexit. Indeed, Mr Farage should urge his ex-Tory voters to back Boris. Because this is not over.Andthe Tories fall agonisingly short, Brexit will be lost and Mr Farage’s party will deserve the blame.HOW can Labour, panicked by the polls, seriously now hope to pass themselves off as a Leave party  They betrayed their Leave voters and everyone knows it.Corbyn wants his Remainer lackey Keir Starmer to “negotiate” a new deal tying us into Brussels’ customs union forever.  That’s Remain in all but name.He would then hold a rigged second referendum pitting this Remain option against actually Remaining in full. His party will campaign for the latter — and give children and EU migrants the vote.Labour are simultaneously posing as a Remain party in the South while trying to masquerade as Leavers in the North.Candidates like Ed Miliband, who have fought ceaselessly to halt Brexit, pretend they voted to make it happen. title: madeleine mccann chief suspect not martin ney
story: The ex-cop sparked speculation Ney was the prime suspect after saying in an interview earlier this year investigators were focusing on a German paedophile in prison.Madeleine disappeared days before her fourth birthday in May  after parents Kate and Gerry left their children in their apartment in Praia da Luz.Amaral was the officer initially in charge of the investigation and made the McCanns arguidos - or official suspects  - before he was sacked from the case.In his interview with an Australian podcast, he mentioned the possibility of a German paedophile being responsible - but he didn’t mention -year-old Hamburg-born child strangler Ney by name.Instead he described the suspect only as someone who had been ruled out of the investigation into the missing British youngster in  but later jailed in his home country.Now Amaral, the original lead investigator in the case, has now said the suspect isn’t Ney, who was jailed for le in  for abducting and murdering three children, and sexually abusing dozens more.When he was shown a photo of him on Spanish TV, Amaral responded: “It can’t be him.”“A paedophile who is German and serving le for killing children has been spoken about,” he told a show about missing adults and children.“What I know is that the suspect is not him, it’s another man. He’s also in prison in Germany. He’s also a paedophile.”In a bizarre twist, Amaral said the suspect looks similar to Madeleine’s dad Gerry before saying that Ney bears no resemblance to him.The slur comes after years of legal wrangling between the former police chief and the missing youngster’s parents over his book ‘The Truth of the Lie.’He claims in the controversial  book that Gerry and Kate McCann had covered up their daughter’s accidental death in their holiday apartment.The McCanns have made a last-ditch attempt to the European Court of Human Rights after losing a libel fight against Mr Amaral in Portugal.Last year Amaral claimed MI spies had helped to cover up Madeleine’s death and disappearance.He said British secret agents “for sure had an involvement” in an Australian documentary which aired in April .The McCanns have repeatedly said the fake accusations against them have harmed the search for Madeleine.Scotland Yard launched its Operation Grange investigation in  and still has a team working on the youngster’s disappearance.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amazon alexa christmas present reveal

title: hangover cure myths expert hangover guide mornings
story: Nutrition expert Sheree Cox has looked at many cures and says: “Having a fry-up is a myth, and don’t be tempted by the hair of the dog.” Here, Sarah Arnold shares the expert’s hangover guide.TOO much wine causes inflammation, which in turn causes white blood cells to flood the bloodstream with proteins called cytokines – the same cells released when you get flu.The result is a headache, nausea and tiredness.A banana will restore potassium that has been lost due to alcohol’s diuretic effect, while a can of  sugary Sprite will boost flagging energy and restore fluids.STUDIES have shown that certain “aged” foods and drinks, such as ripened wines, can cause our bodies to release histamines causing allergy-related symptoms such as dry eyes and a thumping head.Tackle them with cashew nuts to boost energy, plus an anti- histamine tablet to counter allergic symptoms and a glass of hot water with honey to replace lost sugars.WHILE Gin O’Clock may have seemed like a good idea last night, the hangover can be horrendous.A mug of water with fresh ginger should settle the tum, while toast with honey contains fructose which hastens the metabolism of alcohol.A British Medical Journal study found vodka is least likely to give you a hangover – so go Russian instead FOR a beery hangover, eggs and avocado on brown toast instead of a greasy fry-up – which will only irritate the stomach further – will hit the spot.Eggs are rich in protein and vitamin B, which aid detox as they contain cysteine, an amino acid that breaks down the toxic by-products resulting from alcohol in the body.A strong tea or two helps to rehydrate. But curing a beer belly is a whole other matter.MOST of the glamour and lightness that we associate with champagne is because of the fizz in your mouth.But these benign bubbles actually cause epic headaches, as the alcohol gets absorbed faster.The cure – a full-sugar cola – boosts sugar levels, while its caffeine perks you up. Have it with some grilled bacon, which has lots of B vitamins, which act as a catalyst to help to get the alcohol in your system to break down.CIDER or scrumpy is one of the worst drinks for causing morning-after stomach bloat. Add fresh ginger to hot water, with a teaspoon of sugar or honey to replace lost sugars and settle your tum.If all  fails, have some chicken soup.It rehydrates and replaces lost salts and is high in tryptophan, an amino acid that helps your body produce serotonin, improving mood.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour respect brexit referendum vote leave it out
story: Just watch Labour pretend to love Leave!This campaign has been a disaster for Jeremy Corbyn and all his ­middle-class Marxist comrades.Policies that seemed so wonderfully woke in an Islington patisserie — no immigration controls, tax everybody until they squeak — have gone down like a tide of toxic waste out in the real world.Labour thought they could do it without the working class. They were WRONG. All those Labour toffs thought they could live without all of us thick, ignorant peasants who dared to disobey the establishment and vote for Brexit.Emily Thornberry — Lady Nugee, who chuckled at seeing the flag of  St George! — was wrong. Sir Keir Starmer, so passionate in his adoration of Brussels, was wrong.Corbyn — a man without a patriotic bone in his withered old carcass — was wrong. Labour’s total contempt for the working class, who they were founded to represent, has them stumbling towards defeat.So Labour are rethinking their General Election strategy.In Leave-voting areas, Labour will get down on their knees and beg the working class to come home.Even an unequivocal Remainer like Ed Miliband is pretending he has always fought for a Brexit deal.No, Ed — you fought to keep us in a single market and a customs union. You fought for a Brexit that was unworthy of the name.You fought for a deal that was worse than staying in the EU.Labour should really stop fibbing to the British people.The modern Labour Party has no love, affection or understanding of the working class. It is the Tories who now represent the values of  the working man and woman — their patriotism, their belief in democracy, their belief in family  and hard work.In working-class communities, Labour are ludicrously flexing their non-existent Leave credentials — which is both bitterly ironic and horribly hypocritical.Ask all the decent Labour MPs who have suffered torrents of abuse from Labour’s online thugs for ­daring to suggest that the Referendum result, and democracy itself, should be respected.Labour are the Remain party who are too pathetically gutless to admit it. But this election is not simply about Brexit.Infinitely more important than our relationship with the European Union is stopping an economically moronic, terrorist sympathiser like Corbyn from getting anywhere near  Downing Street.I have only ever been a member of one political party — Labour.It was the party of my family, my neighbourhood and my class.That party no longer exists.Corbyn and his Marxist muppets have ruined Labour with their sickening Jew-baiting racism, their puerile class war, their total lack of understanding of even basic ­economics.Do not let them ruin the country.Do not believe the lies that they are going to tell you over the next  days.Andyou are working class, never believe for a single second that this pathetic excuse for a ­Labour Party is on your side.Labour have thrown in their lot with privately educated revolutionaries who would rather wave a Palestinian flag than the Union Jack.And it is only now they are starting to regret it.TOSSING back her golden tresses, Charlize Theron wears a gold dress against a golden background in an ad for Dior’s J’Adore perfume – which comes in a golden bottle.It is like being buried in an avalanche of Ferrero Rocher chocolates.And that’s a compliment.And because he wasn’t there, he must also have invented the scene where a young Prince Charles sobs because he has been forced to break up with a hot young Camilla.And far more offensively, Morgan is surely making it all up when he depicts the Queen faking a tear as she witnesses the horror of  Aberfan.All the real-le photos of the Queen visiting the tragic Welsh mining village show her looking shocked  beyond belief.I do not believe she faked a tear for the cameras.I enjoy The Crown but it is only a posh EastEnders.Don’t mistake it for anything resembling  historical truth.WHAT happened to Katie Price’s £million fortune Just guessing here – she spent it.I will leave it to others to analyse Katie’s profligacy with money and just say this in her defence.She has been a loving mother to her children, including her blind, autistic son Harvey, now , who she seems to have raised single-handedly.She is an inspiration to any parents raising a disabled child.  She has confronted the evil bullies who have mocked her son.She has been a passionate campaigner to hold social media s to account and make online abuse a criminal offence.I don’t think there is anyone in the country who has been more willing to stand up to bullies than Katie.And now she is bankrupt, owing £, to her creditors.I suspect she has faced bigger battles than bankruptcy.THE Liberal Democrats thought vowing to immediately cancel Brexit when Jo Swinson becomes Prime Minister would be a vote winner.Whoops! Now the Lib Dems are desperately offering a second Referendum.Whoops again!Because millions of us hope we never see another referendum in our letime.Paul has had more barmaids than the Rovers Return.VICTORIA Beckham’s  fashion empire has lost a jaw-dropping £million over  years.So who is doing Victoria’s financial planning Diane Abbott CLIVE James, who has died at the age of , was always the smartest man in the room.I met him a few times over the years but the Australian journalist, broadcaster and wit was best experienced on the page and on TV. That is when you got the full force of his brain, which was the size of a planet.Clive was also that great rarity – a true intellectual who was a laugh.As a TV critic, he brought his savage wit to bear on the nuttiest nooks and crannies of global television. As a writer, he was funny, wise and often deeply moving.When Princess Diana died, Clive wrote an unforgettable eulogy in the New Yorker magazine. It recalled how he met her, how their friendship grew and how, at their last lunch in Kensington Palace with -year-old Prince Harry present, he realised that he was about to be dropped from Diana’s court.“I never saw her again,” James concluded. “Neither will anyone  now.”I loved Clive because he made great writing look easy and he made me laugh.As recently as one week ago, a magazine asked Clive what was bothering him at the moment.“Imminent personal extinction,” he replied.And it is a mark of Clive James’ genius that I can’t imagine anyone  in the world coming out with that hilariously honest quip.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour hopefuls betray voters stop brexit
story: They have sworn a pledge to keep Britain in the EU after publicly insisting they would respect the referendum result.Follow our general election live blog for all the latest news and updates...About  wannabe MPs are standing in seats where a majority of people voted to leave the EU.But despite previous vocal support for getting Brexit done, they have all signed the Remainer pledge to sell their prospective constituents down the river.The great betrayal will undermine leader Jeremy Corbyn’s big push to woo back Leave voters in Labour heartlands where support is crumbling.One worried party insider said: “These areas are overwhelmingly in favour of Brexit but those who want to be their Labour MPs are sworn to blocking it. title: politics jeremy corbyn party
story: Come what may, on December  our country will be led by  Boris Johnson orJeremy Corbyn,   who was aptly described by Molly Bennett, , this week as “the red man” who “doesn’t like  Jewish people”.We have been bombarded with muddied interpretations of how the tax system works, a startling lack of understanding of financial reserves and national debt, and delusion on the negative impact renationalisation would have on millions of families.So is it any wonder we are all at sixes and sevens as we head into this festive season Allow me to present my survival guide to the run-up to Christmas.If you are wondering how to stay festive when there is a General Election,  my advice is to get out and party!It might sound counter-intuitive but look at it this way: There’s nothing like a group huddle during periods of uncertainty, whether it’s to celebrate the result you hoped for, or to drown your sorrows and commiserate.So send the invites out and crack open some beers.Apart from anything , it might be the last party you can affordLabour get in.All that said, allow me to suggest caution when it comes to the office party.Whatever you do at the bash, don’t get too drunk.  Yes, I know it’s sometimes free booze. And  I understand the desire to let yourself off the leash. But it might be one of the few times you find yourself in the same room as your boss — with a chance to impress or ruin your career.You’ll be well aware we are living in the #MeToo era. And we all know, on occasions, it can go too far and that we shouldn’t all be frightened about exactly what we say and who to say it to.To allay your fears, my advice to you isyou want to dance with a colleague, ask her. If she says no then that’s your answer.Compliments are fine by the way. Us women love them , but think of your sister when giving them out.“You look great in that dress” is something you’d say to your sister, and “you look hot in that dress” isn’t.If you are looking at the month ahead and feeling overwhelmed already, this is really the only advice that you need: Start delegating.Write a list of all the jobs that need to be done and then allocate jobs to everyone over the age of ten.Getting your family to pull their weight is the best way to ensure that everyone has a happy Christmas.I know a lot of people dread the season, partly because they have to spend time with tricky in-laws.You can either not invite them  — why ruin your day   — or invite others too . Or just grin and bear it.Lastly,you are struggling with presents, please allow me to share the rules of our traditional Brady Family Christmas Present Game, played by the  members of our family on Christmas Day.Everyone buys four gts, having set a price limit: We have three at £, one at £.Wrap each one beautully so it’s impossible to distinguish premium from Primark. I once placed a roll of toilet paper with Donald Trump’s face on it in a Chanel gt bag — it was the hotly contended present everyone wanted that year . . . until they opened it.You place all gts on the table then take it in turns to throw a dice. When you get a six you pick anyone present you want . Keep throwing until all gts are distributed.Then throw six rounds with two dice and for every six you get you can pinch a present from anyone’s pile.And when it’s done you keep and open the presents you have won. It keeps us occupied for hours.I LOVED the photos of Kelly Brook in the Bahamas, where she is celebrating turning . What a great advert she is for the idea that le begins at !Kelly is naturally beautul with a big smile – and I think she looks absolutely amazing.“Lord Sugar couldn’t relate to me. That was the fundamental problem.“And I started getting that feeling from about week four.”The problem with interviews like this is that it puts her in danger of sounding a little bit like a sore loser.Oh, and also, I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but Lord Sugar doesn’t particularly like any of them at the moment.CONGRATULATIONS to builder Steve Thomson, , and his we Lenka, , who scooped the  £million EuroMillions jackpot.All their neighbours have said it couldn’t happen to a nicer couple. And I love the fact that the first thing they want to do with the money is given each of their three kids their own bedroom. This is a fairly humble ambition when you consider they are now one of the biggest British Lottery winners of all time.I also love the fact that Steve said he won’t stop working as a builder and will finish all his jobs before Christmas.He’s also already spelled out to his children thatthey want something “you’ll have to earn it”.All of which reveal an outlook that will stand him in very good stead indeed. It might just mean that he will be able to enjoy his win.The fact is money does change people. It also changes the way others see you. Most families will expect something and when they don’t get it will be angry. They will say things such as “we only want a car . . . it’s not much money for you, but would mean a lot to us”.They will expect you to share out your good fortune.My advice would be to think carefully about what to do with it before you make any rash decisions – and get a very good financial adviser.The problem with people who win a lot of money is that they often totally abandon all their values and spend, spend, spend. Let’s hope Steve and Lenka hold on to theirs.Yes, sure, I can see the temptation to magically get rid of the weight that inevitably comes when you have been, you know, growing another human being inside your body.But she only had a baby six weeks ago and,she waits a bit, she’ll probably just lose the baby weight naturally.In the meantime, yet another celeb demonstrates – and adds to – the pressure to “snap back” to their pre-pregnancy figure within weeks! Yes, your body is important but so is your mind!Six weeks after birth seems too soon to me.EVENit is true that the new Calornian craze of “butt sunning” gives you “surges of energy”, better sleep and “more creativity flowing through le”, which is what one devotee called Meagan promised on a recent Instagram post, I can’t see it catching on here.Meagan  says she has incorporated “perineum sunning” – which involves presenting the area between the anus and vulva to the sun – in to her “daily rising routine”.But talk about the sun shining out of your ar*e…what on earth must the neighbours think.ULRIKA JONSSON is on a dating app for people over   Good for her. She deserves another chance at happiness –  and at  she’s got a lot of le ahead of her.A lot of jokes are made at the expense of Ulrika’s love le and the fact she has had four kids by four men. I can’t help thinking it would be discussed in a dferent wayshe was a man.I KNOW some people are annoyed that Uber will not be granted a new licence to operate in London after repeated safety failures.But I think it’s great news. The reason that the licence hasn’t been granted is because Transport For  London said that the taxi app was not “fit and proper” as a licence holder.I can see the appeal of Uber – but notthe price we are paying is safety.Also, we are lucky enough to live in a country that has the best black cab drivers in the world – who know where they are actually going because they train for up to four years.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: alex t smith books for schools
story: The creator of the bestselling Claude books — now a popular telly show — has called The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign “truly wonderful”.Alex, who is originally from Coventry, says: “By getting books into schools, The Sun is giving children the key to a magical new world. It’s is a wonderful thing.“I’ve always loved reading. Books are a huge part of my le.“I was helping my parents clear out the attic recently and I discovered a piece I’d written in reception where I said I liked reading, writing and drawing. My le was laid out there!”We have an amazing £million worth of books up for grabs for primary schools in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.One in three primary schools has now signed up to collect tokens like the one printed right.Registered schools that collect , tokens will be sent a box of books, worth more than £, from the Collins Big Cat reading programme.Alex’s new series, Mr Penguin, has won multiple awards. It is aimed at slightly older children, aged six to eight. The books are full of slapstick humour and quirky illustrations.Alex, , who grew up in a house where books were plentul, adds: “Both of my parents were teachers — and went on to become headteachers — so there were always books in the house. My grandfather was a writer and librarian, so every week when I spent time with him I had the run of the library too.“Reading is how I learnt about myself. When I was four, I wanted to be a rabbit when I grew up.“I used to convert a chair into my own little hutch. I would drape a blanket over the top of it and go into my hutch with my book, sketchbook and pencils. I was totally happy. The first book that sparked something in me was The Tiger Who Came To Tea by Judith Kerr.“I loved the idea something so extraordinary can happen right in the middle of a very domestic setting. It sparked something in me.“For five-year-old Alex, the thought of going to a cafe in the night in my pyjamas seemed like the most exciting thing that could ever happen.”Alex adds: “Even as an adult, reading is something I have to do. If I’ve been incredibly busy and not had so much time to do it, I don’t feel as happy or connected to things.“When I’m working, I listen to audio books. I find they get me in a bookish frame of mind.“I’ve written for children for  years and I love it more than ever. It’s a big honour to write for children. There is something magical about it.”Alex does a lot of school visits and says that is an important part of writing for youngsters. He says: “Children are so sophisticated, funny and weird. Meeting them is really important.“I’d like to think that they look at me and realise drawing can be an actual job too!“It’s very important that children are aware of all the dferent jobs that they can do.“I really do believe that anyone can draw. Of course some people have an innate talent — and I suppose I was quite good naturally. However, I put in hours and hours of practice.“Even now, I love drawing as much as ever.“If ever I’ve got spare time, I’ll more than likely pick up my sketchbook, evenI’ve been drawing all day.”. title: london bridge hero lucasz medal
story: The hero, who is believed to be a Polish chef by the name Lukasz, was released from hospital today after he courageously helped bring down convicted terrorist Usman Khan with others on London Bridge on Friday.Khan, , was shot dead by police after he went on a rampage in a fake suicide vest and stabbed a man and a woman to death and putting another three in hospital.A work-mate told had told The Sunday Mirror: Lukasz was in the hospital.It is unclearhe was one of the three people taken to the Royal London Hospital in East London along with two other women.Dr Vin Diwakar, Medical Director for the NHS in London, said today one person had been released from the hospital and two others remain in stable condition.Lukasz, who works in the kitchen at Fishmongers Hall where Khans attack started, is set to be honoured with the Medal for Sacrice and Courage for risking his own le for helping to overpower the terrorist.Jan Kanthak, a spokesman for the ruling United Poland party, tweeted that the minister will be putting in a request to President Andrzej Duda.He added: Łukaszs heroism has an international dimension.Warsaw foreign ministry sources told Polish media Lukasz has been released from hospital, the MailOnline reports.It is understood Polish diplomats are now said to be inc contact with UK police.Authorities are not releasing Lukaszs full name for his protection.Cambridge graduate Jack Merritt, a -year-old course coordinator, is the first victim to be named after his grieving father paid tribute to his son as a beautul spirit.Three people, one man and two women, were rushed to hospital on Friday night - and one was in critical condition, one was stable and a third had less serious injuries.NHS Chief Executive Simon Stevens said yesterday that the one patient who was in critical condition has improved and the condition of the other two was the same.It comes after a woman, who did not give her name,said a woman in her s had slash wounds on her arms and stomach and a man had to be put in an induced coma.Lukasz is one of several bystanders who risked their lives to bring down the London Bridge terrorist.Another hero is a kitchen porter named only as Mohammed who is said to have tackled Khan on his lunch break before going back to wash dishes.Two other men who helped to catch the attacker were fearless tour guides Thomas Gray, , and Stevie Hurst who jumped out of their car to help.Prisoner James Ford, , helped take down Khan while he was on day release.Ford murdered a -year-old disabled girl in  and was at an event about rehabilitating criminals when he stepped in.A British Transport police officer in plain clothes bravely picked up one of the knives from the floor and carried it away from the attacker.Khan, from Staffordshire, was freed last December and police said he was known to authorities after he was convicted in  for terror offences.He was banned from entering London but had a one-day exemption to attend an ex-convict event, it emerged last night.Khan, who was wearing a monitoring tag during the attack, was attending an event on Friday afternoon at Fishmonger’s Hall called ‘Learning Together’.The killer hoodwinked authorities by travelling to the prisoner rehabilitation conference at Fishmongers Hall where he launched his horror rampage.One academic who was there told the Mail On Sunday that Khan suddenly just flipped.The Sun on Sunday revealed Khan was given “special permission” to attend the Cambridge University-run event.Haunting pictures emerged of delegates inside the hall an hour before the carnage. Khan was said to be in the room at the time.He is the first freed terrorist to launch an attack in this country.The Parole Board said in a statement yesterday they had no involvement in Khans release.It added it he appeared to have been released automatically on licence , without ever being referred to the Board.The Medal for Sacrice and Courage is a Polish medal and was created in February .It is called the Medal za Ofiarność i Odwagę in Polish.The medal is awarded to those who risk their lives to save people from drowning, aid the victims of natural disasters, fires, explosions, or other unfortunate circumstances, or protect the property of others during such events.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: general election polls odds win bookies
story: But will Boris Johnson remain our Prime Minister  Heres what the bookies and the latest polls say.Were counting down the days to when Brits take to the polls, so whos got the edge so far The latest Kantar poll taken between November - showed a slight narrowing of the Conservatives lead.Labour has squeezed the governing Tories opinion poll lead to  points from  over the past week.Kantar said that support for Boris Johnsons Conservatives fell two points to  per cent, while Labour was up five points on  per cent.The Liberal Democrats were down two points on  per cent, while the Brexit Party was up one point on three per cent.The poll is the second in two days to show a narrowing of the Tories lead.On Monday, an ICM poll for Reuters gave the Conservatives a seven-point lead, down from ten points a week earlier.The BBC says that, according to poll trends, as of November  SNP had four per cent, the Green party three per cent, and UKIP and Plaid Cymru both have zero per cent.But the picture is predictably complicated.Among young voters aged -,  per cent put environment in their top  issues, compared to  per cent of all Brits.Across all ages, Britain leaving the EU is seen as the most important election issue.This is seen as a priority issue by  per cent of - year-olds, which rises to  per cent among those aged  and older.In November we revealed over , voters in  key constituencies will decide our next PM — and the fate of Brexit.If Boris Johnson is to triumph he needs  marginal Labour and Lib Dem seats to swing his way.The magic number of voters Boris needs to back him in the  key constituencies is ,.On October , MPs approved the PMs call for an election to be held on December .It was Mr Johnsons fourth attempt to have Parliament agree to an election after the Labour Party  blocked the vote three times.Parliament shut down from November .When this happens every seat in the House of Commons becomes vacant with those wishing to remain as MPs having to stand in the forthcoming election.The Prime Minister had vowed to push for an electionthe EU granted a three-month extension for his Brexit bill.Mr Johnson sent a letter to the EU requesting a delay until January  after he was compelled to do so when the Benn Act was passed MPs on October .On October , the EU granted the UKs request for a flextension until January , .The UK can leave before that dateMr Johnsons deal is passed in Parliament.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRosie Marcel is dressed in navy hospital scrubs and trainers – the practical kind you might actually go for a run in, not the trendy kind – and her trademark strawberry-blonde locks are pulled into in a messy bun. If she looks exactly like Holby City’s uptight heart consultant Jac Naylor – the character she’s played for the past  years – it’s because she’s stepped straight off the set and into BBC Elstree’s scruffy backstage green room meeting us between scenes. Thankfully, unlike the frosty-faced, hard-as-nails doc who viewers have grown to love, the real Rosie is warm and open, greeting us with a hug. She sips from a water bottle and has one of those immaculate complexions that suggests she downs two litres of the stuff a day. ‘I can assure you I don’t,’ laughs the actor, who lives with second husband Ben Stacey, a gym owner, their five-year-old daughter, Beau, and their four dogs in St Albans. ‘I’m wearing a lot of make-up! I haven’t resorted to Botox yet, but I’m looking forward to it!’ Settling down on the sofa for a natter, Rosie explains how filming Jac’s harrowing nervous breakdown scene, which airs this week, was traumatic because it mirrored her own le three years ago, when she crashed out with depression, anxiety and depersonalisation disorder. Given your mental health struggles, was it emotional, acting Jac’s breakdown  It was the hardest thing I’ve done in my le. When I was first approached about the storyline, I wasn’t happy at all. In fact, I was frightened. But after a lot of cajoling from my agent and the producers, and talking with my husband, I decided it was an important story to tell on behalf of other working mothers. Can you tell us about your own breakdown  Like many first-time mums, I was overwhelmed. Six months after having a baby by C-section, I ed to working long days and I wasn’t being healthy. Scripts were coming in very late and none of what I was reading made sense. One day, I just lost it and shouted at people that they were stopping me from seeing my kid and having a le. A director marched me off set, I called my doctor and I was signed off work immediately.  What were you eventually diagnosed with  Stress, anxiety and depersonalisation disorder – that means you don’t feel like you’re in your own body, you don’t recognise yourself. I remember going home, getting into my pyjamas and looking down on myself asfrom a dferent part of the room. In that moment, I decided everyone would be better off without me. I walked out of the house, without my phone or anything, with no intention of coming back. I turned up at my friend’s house having no idea how I got there. It was pretty scary. How did you get better  I found a therapist. I was reluctant at first because, in all honesty, I saw it as a sign of weakness. My siblings and I were all brought up to be strong iniduals. My mother left when I was very young and we learnt to look after ourselves. I’m a very strong person on the outside. But that all caught up with me.  It’s brave to open up, though... I don’t like people to see I’m vulnerable, but by putting my struggles out there, I hope to help people. All the comments I’ve received have been positive, which is rewarding. Let’s face it, the rest of what I do is just telly, isn’t it  I spent a lot of my childhood wanting people to like me. But I’ve given up on that –you don’t like me that’s fine. I’m  and I finally like myself. How much of your own experience did you bring to your breakdown scenes  Everything. I had a say in the scripts and was allowed a day a week for therapy. I absolutely needed to talk it out, after putting myself back in a vulnerable position. I found it very distressing, watching the scene back where Jac totally loses it in front of her daughter and needs restraining, as did my husband. I still get anxiety about it. I was in a really tired, dark place at the end of filming, so I took three weeks off. I slept a lot and did normal things: I took my kid to school, I walked my dogs, I cleaned my house, I cooked for my family – all the things I really enjoy. If I weren’t at Holby, I would absolutely be a housewe!  How do you stay mentally strong now  Therapy will always be part of my le. I’m lucky enough to be able to afford it. I meditate for  minutes every day and haven’t drunk alcohol in two years. I really miss a lovely glass of red wine, but it’s not good for my mental health. How are your other health issues  You’ve battled endometriosis, haemophilia, the inflammatory disease Behcet’s, and cervical cancer  I’m a bit of a mess, aren’t I  I’ll be on immunosuppressants my whole le. I do feel terribly sorry for myself some days and I sit and cry, but I pick myself up. I’ve got a strong personality and, as an ill person, I don’t like to be told I can’t do things. I enjoy a challenge – I’d love to do something like … and would be horribly competitive. But I’m such an animal lover, I’m not sure how I would manage eating kangaroo balls!    Is Ben very supportive  He knows me better than anyone  and has seen parts of me no one  has. He’s seen me walk out in the middle of the night and not come back, and seen me not being safe to be around my daughter – not that I would ever have been a risk to her, but I was just in such a bad place. And he’s the person who says to me, ‘You need to see your therapist.’ He spots it in me before I do. He’s very good. I know when he’s stressed because he throws himself into a workout.  Do people sometimes think you’re a real doctor  My grandmother would often show me a mark on her arm, asking, ‘What do you think it is ’ I’d keep telling her, ‘I don’t know. I’m not actually a doctor.’ Once a girl fainted right in front of me and someone shouted, ‘Help her!’ and I shouted back, ‘I don’t know what I’m doing!’ What’s the weirdest place you’ve been asked for a selfie  Disneyland. I posed wearing a pair of Mickey Mouse ears, embarrassing! How will you spend Christmas this year  We have friends coming – we’re godparents to their children – and I’ll cook. I can’t stand turkey – it’s too dry for me – so I’ll do a chicken and a proper glazed ham with Yorkshire puds.  The tree won’t last five minutes as we have four dogs – it’ll be chaos! Last year, I went a bit OTT with gts and Beau said halfway through the present-opening, ‘I don’t want to open any more’. I love watching old films with her – Annie, Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Elf. Then I’ll take the leftover ham to enjoy with my sister on Boxing Day – she’s over from LA.

Now, itaposs either some complicated science fiction adaptation or – here we go again – another bloody general election debate. The line up for this one, staged by ITV in Salford, included two  debutants: UKIPaposs – sorry, the Brexit Partyaposs – Nigel Farage and, for Labour, Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon. Seasoned Westminster watchers found the choice of Burgon somewhat, um, courageous, shall we say  But remember Labouraposs switch last week to thrust forward frontbenchers with regional accents who are not wedded to staying in the EU. This, of course, is aimed at shoring up the Red Wall the party fears will fold to the Brexit-backing Tories. There were surely inaudible groans when host Julie Etchingham told us this latest showdown would last two hours.But Julie thataposs, like, longer than a football match. Even factoring in VAR. Tory representative Rishi Sunak, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, set the tone in his opening statement, telling viewers: “You, me, everyone is fed up. We just want to move on.” I agree but steady on, mate, weaposre only four minutes in. Turns out he was on about Brexit. Again. “Letaposs Get This Debate Done,” he didnapost actually say. Farage branded Boris Johnsonaposs deal a “half in, half out fudge”. This after embattled Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson said the Prime Minister couldnapost be bothered to come because “heaposs leaving it to his cheerleader Nigel Farage – andthey win, we lose”. That she was using this attack line so early suggested two things:  she finally realises her campaign really is going badly as she was warned it might and  she didnapost have much faith in viewers lasting the course to pm. Green co-leader Sian Berry was earnest, plausible and likeable – and you wonderone day voters will come to regret not listening earlier and more closely to her partyaposs message on the environment. Farage, who thrives on primetime exposure, power without responsibility and pumping out populist rhetoric, was, predictably, aiming to secure his core vote rather than widen his appeal. In that, he will surely have succeeded. And when he launched adefence of his pal Donald Trump over his “pussy-grabbing” comments it was classic Farage playing to a populist base. It was crass and crude and wrong and men say dreadful things sometimes”, said Farage.  He added that men were likely to say such things after “a night out with a drink” - ignoring the fact Trump is teetotal. And he may have stripped away some Tory votes in Leave-supporting areas the Conservatives must win for a Commons majority. Oh, and he had by far the best tie. Plaid Cymruaposs Adam Price was less good than at Fridayaposs debate in Cardf, now the novelty value has worn off.  Wide-eyed and raging, he was certainly not trying to win over would-be voters with calm authority, displaying instead flaming passion. Passion for Remain. When his party is only standing candidates in a nation that voted to Leave. And he turned the air blue when he said “pussy” on air an hour before the watershed, in relation to Trumpaposs infamous comments grabbing women.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen I was a kid, I was convinced I was going to be a star, because I was always told I was good in the village productions. And why wouldn’t I be a star  I was  years old, and my brother Chris, then , had been considered talented too, and look what he’d achieved. He was in Coldplay. And really, really famous. I’m the youngest and Chris is the oldest. Our second-oldest brother, Al, is an architect, our sister, Rosie, is a nurse and our other brother, Richard, is in the Army. I’m an actor and my parents say all their children are ‘working towards their potential’. I have two side jobs too, just to keep a bit of money coming in: I’m a kids’-party entertainer and transcribe interviews for people. Of course, my surname is Martin, but I changed it to Wren – after a Pizza Express pizza I’m fond of – when I started acting. There was another Nicola Martin on the acting directory, and I also had this fear people would think, ‘Oh, it’ll be easy for her – Chris can get her work.’ I wanted to do it for myself. As the youngest of five kids, all I ever wanted was for my siblings to think I was fab at everything I did. That’s maybe why I secretly want to be a bit famous – it’s love and validation. But anyone with lots of siblings will know what it feels like to grow up in someone’s shadow, Coldplay or no Coldplay.  There’s always a favourite – although I don’t actually think Chris is the favourite in our family! Growing up, I knew he was talented and, because we had the biggest age gap, there was less rivalry between us. He’d make up silly songs about me and my pet gerbils, and send me funny postcards when he went away. He was my hero and I just absolutely adored him. I was eight when Coldplay got together, and  when Chris met Gwyneth Paltrow. That’s when things got a lot bigger for him.  I was doing quite a bit of acting and thought I was the big cheese of the village. I’d landed the part of Mole in The Wind In The Willows and believed it was my big moment. I was peeping through the curtain and, just as the show started, I saw two people sneak in wearing caps. I realised it was Chris, with this woman I’d met a few weeks earlier backstage at a Coldplay concert. I remember other people being really excited, but the name Gwyneth Paltrow meant nothing to me at my age. I didn’t know she’d appeared in Shakespeare In Love and I genuinely thought, ‘Yeah, she acts, but I bet she never played Mole.’  After the show, I ran backstage, ready for my praise and Chris and Gwyneth were there, surrounded by people, with everyone wanting photos and autographs. I was really confused – why didn’t anyone want my autograph ! In hindsight, I realise that was when I changed from being the deluded little girl who thought she was a huge star to being seen as Chris Martin’s little sister. When Coldplay first started getting big, Chris would say to me, ‘Let’s go out and get recognised!’ It was a fun game we liked to play because it was only ever fans of the band and only a few people. But when Gwyneth arrived it was a totally dferent type of recognition. Paparazzi would wait outside our house and hide in our garden. That wasn’t very nice.  My parents explained I wasn’t to speak to them as they were sneaky. That’s when I realised I didn’t really know who to trust and I started not wanting people knowing Chris was my brother. Chris and Gwyneth lived in London together, but they’d come to the village for Christmas. After my niece, Apple, was born, the press would be waiting outside trying to get a glimpse. Although I wanted to be an actor, I didn’t see Gwyneth as a big star. All I cared about was that she was my brother’s cool girlfriend who showed me affection and was so kind to me. She was awesome. I went to boarding school a year after they met and I tried not to tell anyone Chris was my brother.  Only I was so homesick, she called and spoke to me every single day. We were really close and especially as a younger sister, when your older brother has a cool girlfriend, you love them. I remember in Home Economics we were making woolly hats and I made two. One for Gwyneth and one for my other brother’s girlfriend at the time. I gave it to Gwyneth and remember thinking, ‘I bet she’s going to get papped wearing that hat.’ I never saw her wear it! It was a shit hat, but I’d done her favourite colours. She was very appreciative and sweet when I gave it to her though. Despite the mega-fame in Chris’s le, the rest of the family all lived normally.  I graduated from drama school and went over to LA to visit him. Gwyneth said she’d take me to the Golden Globes. She helped me pick a dress and get ready, and that was the first time I thought, ‘This is absolutely mental.’ There were brilliant actors all around me and I was thinking, ‘When I get home, I’m back to working in a pub.’ People assume I have a lavish lestyle and Chris bankrolls me, but I’d never ask him for anything – he has his own family. We were always taught the value of money. I needed a new bike recently and some friends said, ‘Can’t Chris pay for it ’ No. It’s nice to save up and buy things yourself. But I’m fortunate thatI was down on my luck, I have people who can help.  My dating le has been tricky with a famous brother. A boy dumped me because he was in a band and was worried people would think he was using me to get to Chris. That was really hard for  him , apparently! I broke up with someone recently in the pub and my brother’s song  The Hardest Part  was playing. And, sometimes, I’ll beon a date, snogging, and a Coldplay song will come on. It’s too weird! Of course, there’s part of me that loves it, becausesomeone dumps me, at least they’ll think about me loads afterwards because they’ll hear Coldplay wherever they go!  I used to pretend I hated the band, as I thought that was cooler, but I’m not afraid to admit I love them now. Their music gives me great comfort and I like taking my friends to their gigs, as they’re brilliant live.

title: two year old girls refusal
story: NewsWe didnt worry when -year-old refused to use potty - then her lips went blueFor most kids, Christmas Eve is all about Santa’s visit – but for the family of Evie Hughes from Stockton-on-Tees, it marked the start of a gruelling and painful cancer battleShareCommentsBySusanna Galton:,  DEC NewsEvie was only two when she was diagnosed with stage  neuroblastoma"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was back in November  when Lynsay Hughes and her husband Andrew, a project engineer, both , first noticed their two-year-old Evie was out of sorts.‘We’d begun potty training and it was going really well, but Evie suddenly started refusing to go to the toilet and got very whingy,’ explains Lynsay, a swimming teacher.‘She’d been quite a sickly baby, so initially we didn’t think much of it.’ When Evie went off her food, got dark circles under her eyes, and seemed to have no energy, Lynsay took her to the GP. The little girl was then referred to North Tees Hospital, near the family’s home in Stockton-on-Tees.She spent five days there, before eventually being diagnosed with a chronic kidney infection, and discharged. ‘I just wanted to get her home for Christmas,’ says Lynsay, also mum to Oscar, now nine.‘She was fine for a few days and then her health plummeted – her legs, feet and fingers began to swell and her lips went blue. ‘Andrew took her to the park and she vomited everywhere. We knew something wasn’t right.’ Lynsay went back to hospital, where Evie was given an ultrasound.‘A doctor came out and said, “Do you want to wait for your husband ” but I never dreamed it would be anything serious so I said, “No, just tell me now.”‘He explained that while he wasn’t a paediatric expert, they had found a mass around Evie’s tummy and wanted us to be transferred to specialists at the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle. ‘Andrew met us at the bigger hospital – we knew it was more serious, but I still wasn’t thinking about cancer.‘Even when we went to meet an oncology consultant, I wasn’t panicking because I honestly didn’t know what the word meant. ‘The first time we realised it was cancer was when a doctor came in the room and said, “I’m going to take a biopsy of Evie’s tumour.”‘What – she had a tumour  Andrew and I just looked at each other in shock.’ The couple were soon ushered into a room full of dferent medical people – consultants, nurses, anaesthetists – and were told the devastating news: Evie had stage  neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is a very rare childhood cancer that affects only about  children a year in the UK. ‘I was in complete shock,’ recalls Lynsay.‘I said to the doctor: “Are you telling me my daughter has cancer ” he replied: “I’m not just telling you she has cancer, I’m telling you she has the beast of childhood cancers.” Those were his exact words.‘Andrew burst into tears, but I couldn’t take it in, I just held his hand feeling gutted, totally heartbroken.’ It was on  December  when that devastating diagnosis was confirmed: Evie had a cm tumour – the most aggressive kind – which was wrapped around her main artery.The disease had also spread to her bones. Knowing staff would be short for the festive season, doctors moved quickly.  On Christmas Eve, the poorly toddler began her first, gruelling round of chemotherapy. ‘It was only when Evie had her line to receive her chemotherapy fitted into her little body that the enormity of the situation finally sank in,’ admits Lynsay. ‘I let out some noise that Andrew tells me was like a shriek and I fell to the floor. It was like the world had stopped.‘But somehow we dragged ourselves through Christmas, trying to put on brave faces to watch Oscar open his presents.‘Evie was too poorly to care about gts.’ Unbelievably traumaticThe next year went in a blur of treatment and surgery. Evie was put on a -day cycle of dferent chemotherapy drugs for  days to target the disease in her bones.Then she had the tumour surgically removed, a stem cell harvest, high intensity chemotherapy with stem cell replacement, and radiotherapy every day for three weeks.She was also put on a clinical trial for immunotherapy, designed to kill the bad cells while protecting the healthy ones for a further six months. ‘It was unbelievably traumatic. If Evie woke up in a dferent room to the one she went to sleep in, orwe weren’t there, she would scream and scream.‘We explained to her that she had a nasty bug in her tummy and the doctors were giving her medicine which would make her feel funny but would make her better in the end.‘We named her feeding tube Tommy and her chemo drips Wally and Dolly, to try and make things less scary for her. ‘She took her beloved Teddy everywhere. ‘When Evie’s blonde curls fell out in lumps, my friend who is a hairdresser came and cut it into a bob for her.‘We told her she had superpowers, that’s why her hair had fallen out.  ‘Her big brother, Oscar, was so sweet when he came to the hospital, he would make friends with the other children on the ward and be so protective of her. ‘There were times when I was terried she might die, but I just willed her to be better and wouldn’t allow myself to think the worst. ‘We put on a brave face at home for Oscar, but when I was in bed I would cry and cry and my heart would be racing with the anxiety and stress.‘I just had to focus on the next part of the treatment.‘In between we tried to do nice things – we took her to The Lion King in London as a treat, and we went camping in the Lake District.’ Lynsay gave up teaching swimming to be with Evie full time, Andrew cut down his hours as a project engineer, and Lynsay’s sister would take care of Oscar when both parents had to be at hospital. Our best Christmas Finally, in March , after more than two years of treatment, the family received the news they had been longing to hear: Evie was cancer-free and in remission.To mark the momentous occasion, the hospital have a special ‘end of treatment’ bell that children get to ring at the end of their chemotherapy. ‘It was a huge day for us.‘Evie wore a new dress with rainbows on it, and our whole family came to the hospital to watch her ring the bell.‘We all cried buckets. ‘Afterwards, we went to a restaurant in Newcastle where everyone made a fuss of her and had a big party, with Evie getting a knickerbocker glory. ‘She’s two and half years in remission now and living a normal, healthy le.‘She’s in Year One at school, has lots of friends, and her hair has grown back. She loves dancing and drama and riding her bike. ‘This Christmas we will be surrounded by our family at our home – and we are determined to enjoy every second.‘Evie is madly into Barbies and Frozen and can’t wait for Father Christmas to come. She’s definitely been good!‘And we have the best present you could possibly imagine – our family, together.’ ■

story: NewsI escaped paedophile step-dad after Corrie abuse plot gave me courage to speakEXCLUSIVE: Watching the controversial Bethany Platt storyline convinced the -year-old to confide in a friend - her abuser was later jailed after she gave evidence against him in courtShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  NOV Updated:,  DEC NewsCoronation Streets abuse storyline encouraged the -year-old to speak out about her own abuse at the hands of her stepfather "Get the biggest soaps stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager who watched Coronation Street with her mum only realised she was the victim of abuse when she saw ­Bethany Platt’s harrowing storyline unfold. The girl, , had been physically and emotionally abused by her stepdad for months after his marriage to her mum broke up. But, like Bethany’s older tormentor on TV, the abuser brainwashed her into believing it was acceptable. Slowly, almost episode by episode, the teenager realised what was happening. And she knew – just as actress Lucy Fallon’s character Bethany did – she had to stand up for herself, she had to speak out. Now, after seeing her abuser jailed, the girl says: “Watching the show I started piecing it all together. At first I thought it was normal because he was my stepdad. “I was a similar age to Bethany in the show and it helped me create a picture of what was happening and what could happenI didn’t say something. “I need to tell my story so others are aware, they can relate to it or give someone going through it the courage to speak.” Her stepdad, who cannot be named to protect her anonymity, was jailed last month for more than two years after being convicted of sexual activity with a child family member. He will be on the sex offenders register for  years. The abuse took place two years ago – at the time of the Corrie plot. Actress Lucy, , was humbled to learn her role convinced the girl to go to the police. Lucy, who has played Bethany for five years, said: “It’s overwhelming to hear this young girl has been able to come forward.” The girl’s ordeal ended after she confronted her stepdad in July . She confided in a friend, who rang the girl’s home. Her mum was horried and called her daughter – as she was being driven home by the stepdad. The girl was hysterical and her mother told her to keep the phone on “speaker” mode so that she could hear everything. The mum takes up the story, saying: “When he arrived he was in tears saying, ‘Sorry, I canapost help it’. I told him I never wanted him near the kids again.”  The mum recalls watching Corrie oblivious to the nightmare her girl was going through. She adds: “We’d watch it and I had no idea it was happening to her. It gave her the courage to confront him and to speak out. I’d been married to him for  years, I was devastated. “Now I hope we never see him again. I’d no idea he was like that. He was playing mental games with her, messaging her, buying her things, groping her. She’s been amazing in reporting him.” The victim, now  and trying to rebuild her le, says her misery began during weekend visits to her stepdad. She says: “It started with him walking in when I was in the bath or as I was getting dressed. He said it was a mistake and it was brushed under the carpet. “I then got constant calls and messages. He started to put his hand on my inner thigh and kissing my neck and shoulders. I told him to stop but he still continued.” The girl’s mum had a breakdown after the marriage split and her ex – much older than her – used this as ammunition. The girl says: “He saidI spoke out I’d be the reason for Mum to have another breakdown. So I kept quiet.” And the abuse went on. The girl says: “He’d buy revealing clothes and repeatedly ask for photos of me wearing them. He also used to buy me alcohol. “I asked, ‘What are your feelings towards me ’ He replied, ‘I love you, but not in a daughter way’. Then he said, ‘It’s okay because most -year-old girls have the mindsets of -year-olds and age doesn’t matter’.”  The girl says that after confronting him he said something along the lines of: “Where do we go from here ” She says that has stuck with her – “and every time I hear those words in my head it makes me feel sick”. The girl gave evidence via video link and went to court to see him jailed last month. Her mum says: “She needed to do that. He had been found guilty and she had been vindicated. “It was a great relief for her that people knew she was telling the truth. It has been hard but she has been so brave.” The girl, due to start counselling in the New Year, adds: “I faced him at sentencing. It’s impossible to explain the emotions I felt. “Although it may seem like it’s over I have suffered mentally and physically. I don’t trust a single soul, I have panic attacks. “My mum has to force me to go to the shops with her. I started to knot my hair and pull it out which is a form of self harm. I did it without knowing. “But now I have the closure I need to move on.” TV star Lucy said: “The storyline was incredibly important to me and it was crucial we got it right and told it with accuracy and care.

title: london bridge re opens after
story: NewsLondon Bridge partially re-opens after terror attack that killed two Cambridge graduatespolitan Police officers say vehicles within the cordons have now been reduced and the roads have been re-opened two days after the attack by terrorist Usman KhanShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsLondon Bridge pictured today, two days after the horror terror attack "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLondon Bridge has partially re-opened following the terror attack which tragically claimed the lives of two Cambridge graduates. politan Police officers said they have been working hard to enable the area to be opened again since Fridayaposs incident. The cordons either side of the bridge have now been reduced and the roads re-opened. However, the bridge itself currently remains closed. The force initially tweeted that the bridge had reopened, however has since confirmed they are still working to do so.A spokesperson said: has tweeted: The cordons either side of London Bridge have been reduced  roads re-opened.The bridge itself currently remains closed  we are working to re-open it. We will update when this happens. Apologies for any confusion and inconvenience caused. Cordons were put in place after the terror attack, which saw Usman Khan stab five people in Fishmongersapos Hall before being held down by members of the public in nearby London Bridge until police arrived and shot him dead. Two of the victims died following the attack. They have been named as Jack Merritt, , of Cottenham, Cambridgeshire and Saskia Jones, , of Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire. Both were graduates of the University of Cambridge and family liaison officers are supporting their families.  Today tributes and flowers were placed on London Bridge after part of a police cordon and some vehicles were moved. One tribute attached to a photo of Jack placed under a road sign read: I have no words. You were so loved and so needed on this planet. Another card attached to the photo said: It may have taken us a long time to realise we would get on but once we did I could do nothing but adore you for being the wonderful and wholly special human being that you are. You have been a light and rock to so many and we love you.  Both victims were involved in the universityaposs Learning Together programme – Jack as a co-ordinator and Saskia as a volunteer.  Terrorist Usman Khan was on licence and wearing an electronic monitoring tag when he launched his attack as he attended the conference on prisoner rehabilitation hosted by the scheme at Fishmongersapos Hall. The University of Cambridge confirmed two of their graduates had been killed and a third member of staff among the injured.  Professor Stephen Toope, vice-chancellor of the University of Cambridge released as statement which read: I am devastated to learn that among the victims of the London Bridge attack were staff and alumni of the University of Cambridge, taking part in an event to mark five years of the Learning Together programme. What should have been a joyous opportunity to celebrate the achievements of this unique and socially transformative programme, hosted by our Institute of Criminology, was instead disrupted by an unspeakable criminal act. I am sad beyond words to report that course coordinator Jack Merritt and former student Saskia Jones were killed. Both were Cambridge graduates.
